Stinchcombe Discusses
Foreign Policy Forum
Members of the faculty have decided
to hold a discussion forum on foreign
policy in Levering Hall following Dean
Rusk's speech tomorrow. The following is an interview conducted with Dr.
Arthur Stinchcombe. Chairman of the
Social Relations Department and head
of the Hopkins branch of The InterUniversity Committee on Foreign P?licy
which will conduct the forum. The
interview was conducted Tuesday evening by N-L staffers Caleb Deschanel
and John Brickman.
NL: Dr. Stinchcombe, can you tell us
something about the Inter-University
Committee?

MOODY
sion of the Shriver Hall lecture.
The more aggressive members of the
group stated an obligation to the International Days of Peace, designated,
world-wide, for Saturday and Sunday.
They stated in addition an importance
of "causing a disturbance inside Shriver
Hall during Rusk's speech to dramatize
our grievance." This move, it was said
"would impress upon Rusk the dissension in the academic community in regard to the administration's policy in
Viet Nam."
The decision, which was eventually
taken against any tactics that would
break up the assemblage, was done so
in recognition of the ultimate detriment
to the University and to the SDS group
by such action. It was taken as well
with the recognition that the object of
the organization is to "expand its organization to include as much of the
community as possible."
And that this goal is furthered by an
appearance of good conduct.
The general tone of the debate was
undoubtedly intensified by the recent
article in the News American evening
edition of October 11, relating the local
student liberal movement to a nationwide Communist action front. This
article was followed by a rebuttal of its
statements by a member of SDS at
Hopkins. Peter Dawidowicz, in an article
on October 12.

5: The Inter-University Committee
on Foreign Policy, consisting of faculty
members from Homewood, the Hopkins
Medical Institutions, Goucher and Morgan State, was founded in order to
provide these faculty members a chance
to discuss current issues in foreign policy and related areas, with the opportunity to call upon expertise certain
members may have in relevant fields.
The general theme we have chosen for
a proposed series of seminars and
luncheon meetings is "Revolution in the
world and the American response."
Vietnam, of course, is the issue which
the United States is putting the most
money into, and will undoubtedly occupy a major portion of our time. But
we intend to consider other fields as
well. For instance, there is a man in
the Social Relations Department—Dr.
Breton—who is French Canadian, and
who is quite interested in the Quebec
separatist movement. A discussion of
this is a possibility. I myself am interested in economic development of Latin
American countries. Time might be
devoted to this.
NL: Could you list the Hopkins faculty members active on the Committee?
S: OK. The people who were at the
organizational meeting on the Home=
wood campus last Tuesday were myself,
Dave Bramhall from Geography, John
Owen from Economics, and Charles
Barker and Steven Ambrose from History. These things are quite informal,
and, you know, you can rank people
according to their level of activity; any
particular meeting will cut that rank in

STINCHCOMBE
a certain place, and the people who
would come to an organizational meeting
are more committed thn those who
don't. So there are others who might
be willing to speak on certain topics of
their competence. You get some people
In the group who are concerned—like
myself—over long term and on a large
number of issues about which it is felt
that American foreign policy is not
based upon an adequate analysis of the
realities of the situation. In other words;
one sort of extreme would be some fundamental dissatisfaction with American
foreign policy. The other sort of extreme might be found in a guy who
was interested in a specific topic and
would be willing to talk to the group
about it. Between these extremes, there
are all grades of people. There've been a
group of people from local campuses
who have been together a number of
years, in a group called the Arms Control Seminar. That includes Barker from
here, Jerome Frank from the Medical
School. and Professor of history William Neumann from Goucher. They
more or less achieved their ends; a book
was published, and besides, they ran
out of money.

Bulletin
A report from Dean Rusk's office in Washington has confirmed
that he has agreed to conduct a
question and answer dialogue
immediately following the address Saturday.
Secretary of State Dean Rusk
will meet with thirty faculty
members and graduate students
tomorrow preceding his scheduled public address in Sheiver
Hall at four p.m. Saturday.
A close personal friend of
Hopkins' president Dr. Milton
Eisenhower, Mr. Rusk had earlier
expressed the desire to meet with
a small number of faculty and
graduate students for an informal exchange of ideas between himself and such a group.
After accepting Dr. Eisenhower's
invitation to speak at Hopkins,
the Secretary of State agreed
that this would be an appropriate time to meet with the
group.
Accordingly, Dr. Eisenhower
asked ten faculty members from
the departments of Political
Science, Political Economy, and
History to attend the meeting.
Each professor was rtquested to
bring two graduate students
whom he felt would especially
benefit from the interview. The
meeting will be closed and offthe-record in order to insure the
informal atmosphere in which
Mr. Rusk wishes to conduct the
seminar.
Following this gathering, the
Secretary of State will deliver
the George Huntington Williams
Memorial Lecture.

STUDENTS & FACULTY

NL: What about student protests extending as far as the
exercise of civil disobedience?
8: I think that sometimes
the administration and faculty
positions will be such as to demand, on the part of the students, in order to defend their
own interests, their freedom of
speech, of their point of view,
something that will involve civil
disobedience — and that doesn't
necessarily mean that I have to
be in favor of it. It's their business whether they undertake
civil disobedience or not. I personally am inclined against civil
disobedience to interfere with a
man talking. But, you know, I
can conceive of circumstances
under which students consider it
important enough to object to
the way a man talks to undertake civil disobedience and if
they were to do it in my class, I
would try to take it like a gentleman. I'm not sure that I
would.
NL: To move on to more immediate considerations, do you
think Secretary Rusk should entertain
after
his
questions
speech?

sity tradition in general. I think
that if a man chooses a university as a public forum, that is
one of the conditions he should
morally be pressured to accept.
However, if he doesn't accept,
I am in favor of letting him talk
anyway.
NL: What Is to be done after
Rusk's speech?

S: Directly after the oonclusion of the lecture, there will be
a discussion of the speech and
relevant issues, to take place in
Levering Hall. In organizing it,
what we tried to do was to recruit faculty members with different points of view who are
competent to talk on the issues:
have them talk for a while, and
then open it up for general discussion as long as it lasts. I will
probably chair the discussion.
Other speakers should be Dr.
Ambrose, who will open it up,
and then Dr. Owen and Dr.
Bramhall. We all should be expected to attack the Administration's foreign policy. Then, we
will have someone who seems
most competent to defend the
Administration's position. We
also thought that Students for a
Democratic Society represented a
particular point of view toward
Rusk and Administration foreign
policy, and that they are a
legitimate part of the dialogue
which should go on in the universities. So we have invited an
SDS spokesman to take part in
the discussion — that is, before
the general discussion.

Sell Out For Ian and Sylvia IFC Revises Rules;
Y Open 'Ti! 1 A.M.
The Fall Weekend, October 2224, this year features: Ian and
Sylvia in concert Friday night,
the Fall Weekend dance Saturday night, and a full program of
Sports through both days.

The IFC is currently making
an extensive revision of fraternity house rules, announced IFC
president Larry Schmidt at Monday's Student Council meeting.
The revision was begun as a
consequence of Dean Morrill's
request that the rules be enforced. Schmidt said that the
present rules were "unrealistic in
view of current practices," and
that if rules were to be enforced,
they should be reasonable. Present rules forbid women above the
first floor or in any bedrooms in
the fraternity houses.
Booster Club President Jeff
Griffith announced an all-school
dance to be held in the gym on
October 23rd. Tickets for this

The concert, sponsored by the
Y.M.C.A., will be held in Shriver
Hall at 8:30 p.m. Regular tickets
for the event were sold out as
Of Tuesday afternoon. Standing
room tickets were put on sale
Wednesday for $1.50; the Y had
Seventy of these.
"Prophet and the Disciples"
are the headliners for the Big
Weekend dance. This is the same
band that played at the Starlighter in May of last year under
the name of "Saber and the
Sensations". Tickets are on sale
today in Levering Hall and in
the snack bar at $3.50 per couple.
The dance will be held in the
Gym at nine o'clock and will last
Until one. Dress will be semiformal and table reservations
can be made at, the Student
Shop. Set-ups will be available at
the Gym. The dance is sponsored
by the Booster Club and the
D.S.R.C.

event will cost $3.50.
In connection with Hopkins
social events, the YMCA announced that it will remain open
until 1:00 A.M. on Saturday
nights to provide a place to go
after dates. Various facilities
will be provided. Plans are also
being made to open the main
dormitory lounge on the weekends.
Barry Gould, representative
from the Honor Commission, expressed the Commission's approval of a Student Council resolution resolution requesting
that exams be given in rooms of
sufficient size to allow students
to sit one seat apart if they
wish to do so.

home sports events over the
Weekend. Saturday. October 23,
features the varsity football, soccer, and cross country teams in
action on the Homewood fields.
At 1:30 p.m. the football squad
goes against Hampden-Sydney
and the cross country team entertains Franklin and Marshall.

We Lead Bad Lines
The News American in a front page lead story
Monday evening suggested that the demonstrations to be
held on campus tomorrow in conjunction with Secretary
of State Rusks Speech have been ordered by the communist party. This kind of statement is the worst
kind of yellow journalism; it should not be found in a responsible newspaper. The source of the correlation between the demonstrations and the communist party comes
from an obscure release from a former FBI counter
spy and ultra rightist advertising man from New Hampshire: Herbert Philhrick. In his news bulletin for September issued several weeks ago, Philbrick states that
the communist party has ordered demonstrations on
college campuses this October in several U.S. Cities.
From this statement the News found an analogy with

By HENRY J. KORN
Dean Rusk's visit to Hopkins
marks the first in a series of
lectures designed to convince the
American academic community
of the soundness of American
Foreign Policy. While we welcome the chance to hear such an
argument straight from the
source's mouth, our feelings in
the matter are naturally tempered by the fact that each one
of us is seated in what could become an ice-cold draft.
On September twenty-eighth,
in Miami Beach, Florida, (site of
Morris Lapidus's "new American
architecture" e.g. The Baltimore
Civic Center), General Louis B.
Hershey, director of the Selective Service, called for the creation of Army units to be made
up of men already rejected by
the draft.
"My plan," said Hershey, "calls
for a two year program for 30,000 rejected from the service.
During last year," he continued,
"we rejected 134,000 men; 54,000
were rejected for moral reasons."
One might wonder if today's
aerospace team is ready for the
fellows numbered in the 54,000?
If so then the result would be a
service reorganization far beyond
the wildest dreams of Robert
McNamara.

the war council af the Joint
Chiefs of Staff? Who would take
the responsibility of giving Saturday night passes to_ the boys
of the Twenty-sixth Regimental
Rapists? How could you protect
infimary supplies from the guys
in the Eighty-second Addicts?
Yet the Inclusion of such perk
sonnel might be of great military
value if they were to be placed
In the field. Such a strategy
might bring an end to North
Vietnamese involvement, since
they might all go home in disgust,

a book entitled "I Lead Three Lives" recounting his ex-

While Herbert Philbrick was undoubtedly a competent counter spy it can hardly be evidence that he is
now competent to make such statements.

periences as a counter spy.
In this well publicized hook, which was later
adapted into a popular television series, Philbrick helped
to expose the communist's conspiracy against the U.S.
by depicting their activities as he noted them while serving as a counter spy. He stated in his book that the
communists seek to split our society and evoke intense
conflict. In a speech at Loyola College here in Baltimore
in April of 1954 Philbrick reiterated this point and stated
that the communists hope to gain control of the government by "eliminating the middle of the roader". He
also advised his Loyola audience not to revert to smear
tactics that split or divide the public and not to look
for communists under every bed. Yet with the release
of his current News Bulletin it appears that Philbrick
has forgotten the lessons he intended to teach the American public. His new found position denies a middle of
the road. The News American in their printing of the
story concerning the News Bulletin never learned the
lesson, if indeed they are concerned.
Such a story as the one that appeared in the News
American creates erroneous impressions about poltical
organizations on campus. For the most part the politicos
at Hopkins are led by responsible students. They generally take an intelligent and mature approach to their
activities and rarely approach the idiotic and dispieable
smear tactics that have been used by Philbrick and The
News American. That the News American should assume
the veracity of statements by Philbrick is questionable;
but to draw upon Philbrick as evidence that the demonstrations here are communist inspired is extremely
obscure.

Mts.--Taylor's Climb To Fame
By MIKE MICHAELSON
It is not uncommon, at an institution like Johns Hopkins, for
an undergraduate to come into
contact with great men. Leading
authors, prominent educators,
and world-renowned leaders of
crucial scientific research are an
Integral part of the total university experience. What is unusual,
however, even in a school of
Hopkins' caliber, is to find an
undergraduate with almost

Daniel Taylor climbs mountans, and he climbs them well.
Although many people still view
mountain climbing as more of a
sport than a true science, Dan
takes his "sport" seriously. What
is more, eminent scientists, proThe
mountaineers,
fessional
Johns Hopkins University, and
the United States Army take
Dan seriously. So seriously in
fact, that Hopkins and the Army
helped finance his three month
summer sojourn in the Himalayas. Tbe results of Dan's expedition: valuable medical and
geological data, and a world's
record for the highest solo traverse in mountaineering history.

Setting out for the Shagri
mountain range in the Himalayas toward the end of May, the
expedition did not return to the
States until the fifth of September. Originally scheduled to
Include three of America's finest
climbers (including Willie Unsold, perhaps the best in the
world, famous for his traverse of
Mt. Everset), the expedition included none of them when it
finally left. Dan was the only
climber of significant experience.
Three previous trips to the
Himalayas had earned Taylor,
who is only twenty, that appellation. Born in the U.S., Dan
moved to India with his family
when he was only two, spending
the next three and a half years
there, and learning Hindi, his
true mother tongue. After two
years in Boston, (his father
taught at Harvard), Dan returned to India for another four
years, this time picking up Punjabi dialects. Home again, and
then, between his sophomore and
junior years in high school, back
to India, this time as a member
of a Harvard Sociological Research Team.

Finally., at the conclusion of
his freshman year at Hopkins,
the most recent and significant
of his expeditions was initiated.
The only American Himalayan
Expedition of 1965, the trip was
financed by a grant from the
United States Army and The
Johns Hopkins University.
Mountain climbing cliches to the
contrary, the Himalayas were
scaled not "because they were
there," but with serious scientific
goals in mind, goals which were
for the most part realized. For
the Army, the members of the
group tested high altitude survival rations to be supplied to
our future astronauts. For Hopkins they brought back species of
high altitude rodents called Marmots, guinea pig-like animals
particularly adaptable to medical
research.
But as far as mountaineering
exploits are concerned, the results were not only satisfactory,
they were spectacular. Dan and
five "first, ascents," climbs of
his companions made a total of
peaks which had never before
been challenged Three of these

notch a victory since their '63
Hopkins game, are, in the words

definite offensive potential.

Urie, a tough inside runner.

felt the team played well enough

Lost Pass Rush

were sometimes too worried
about getting beaten deep and
not enough with breaking up
the passes. We really shut down

their running game, though, and

Calli, along with Oidick and Ray
Nunnaly.

the team returns home to face
Hampden-Sydney October 23
with the kickoff scheduled for
1:30.

The decision, which was eventually
taken against any tactics that would

by such action. It was taken as well
with the recognition that the object of

And that this goal is furthered by an
appearance of good conduct.

5: The Inter-University Committee
on Foreign Policy, consisting of faculty
members from Homewood, the Hopkins
Medical Institutions, Goucher and Morgan State, was founded in order to
provide these faculty members a chance
to discuss current issues in foreign policy and related areas, with the opportunity to call upon expertise certain
members may have in relevant fields.
The general theme we have chosen for
a proposed series of seminars and
luncheon meetings is "Revolution in the
world and the American response."
Vietnam, of course, is the issue which
the United States is putting the most
money into, and will undoubtedly occupy a major portion of our time. But

The News American in a front page lead story
Monday evening suggested that the demonstrations to be
held on campus tomorrow in conjunction with Secretary
of State Rusks Speech have been ordered by the communist party. This kind of statement is the worst
kind of yellow journalism; it should not be found in a responsible newspaper. The source of the correlation between the demonstrations and the communist party comes
from an obscure release from a former FBI counter
spy and ultra rightist advertising man from New Hampshire: Herbert Philhrick. In his news bulletin for September issued several weeks ago, Philbrick states that
the communist party has ordered demonstrations on
college campuses this October in several U.S. Cities.
From this statement the News found an analogy with

Mts.--Taylor's Climb To Fame
By MIKE MICHAELSON
It is not uncommon, at an institution like Johns Hopkins, for
an undergraduate to come into
contact with great men. Leading
authors, prominent educators,
and world-renowned leaders of
crucial scientific research are an
Integral part of the total university experience. What is unusual,
however, even in a school of
Hopkins' caliber, is to find an
undergraduate with almost
equally impressive credentials.
Daniel Taylor climbs mountans, and he climbs them well.
Although many people still view
mountain climbing as more of a
sport than a true science, Dan
takes his "sport" seriously. What
is more, eminent scientists, proThe
mountaineers,
fessional
Johns Hopkins University, and
the United States Army take
Dan seriously. So seriously in
fact, that Hopkins and the Army
helped finance his three month
summer sojourn in the Himalayas. Tbe results of Dan's expedition: valuable medical and
geological data, and a world's
record for the highest solo traverse in mountaineering history.

Setting out for the Shagri
mountain range in the Himalayas toward the end of May, the
expedition did not return to the
States until the fifth of September. Originally scheduled to
Include three of America's finest
climbers (including Willie Unsold, perhaps the best in the
world, famous for his traverse of
Mt. Everset), the expedition included none of them when it
finally left. Dan was the only
climber of significant experience.
Three previous trips to the
Himalayas had earned Taylor,
who is only twenty, that appellation. Born in the U.S., Dan
moved to India with his family
when he was only two, spending
the next three and a half years
there, and learning Hindi, his
true mother tongue. After two
years in Boston, (his father
taught at Harvard), Dan returned to India for another four
years, this time picking up Punjabi dialects. Home again, and
then, between his sophomore and
junior years in high school, back
to India, this time as a member
of a Harvard Sociological Research Team.

Finally., at the conclusion of
his freshman year at Hopkins,
the most recent and significant
of his expeditions was initiated.
The only American Himalayan
Expedition of 1965, the trip was
financed by a grant from the
United States Army and The
Johns Hopkins University.
Mountain climbing cliches to the
contrary, the Himalayas were
scaled not "because they were
there," but with serious scientific
goals in mind, goals which were
for the most part realized. For
the Army, the members of the
group tested high altitude survival rations to be supplied to
our future astronauts. For Hopkins they brought back species of
high altitude rodents called Marmots, guinea pig-like animals
particularly adaptable to medical
research.
But as far as mountaineering
exploits are concerned, the results were not only satisfactory,
they were spectacular. Dan and
five "first, ascents," climbs of
his companions made a total of
peaks which had never before
been challenged Three of these

The intramural sports program got underway as the freshmen opened their football season
by playing three games on
Wednesday, October 6. Gildersleeve and Griffin, two very evenly matched teams, battled to a
nothing to nothing deadlock.
After a five minute overtime
neither team had scored, and the
game ended in a draw.
Adams narrowly squeezed past
Lazear by a score of eight to six.
The Adams house, which caught
three interceptions during the
contest;scored its winning touchdown on a pass from John Pell
to Harry Snider.
Jennings Wins
A spirited Jennings team dominated their game with Baker.
Jennings caught four pass interceptions, three of which were
made by defensive back Bruce
Tarzy. The game was won on a
long touchdown pass from Jenning's quarterback Tom Horn to

end Bob Swann, and the game
ended six to nothing.
In freshman action on October 11, it was Griffin over McKoy, (21 to 7); Adams over
Gildersleeve, (6 to 0); and Baker
over Clark, (13 to 0).
Frats Clash
The fraternities opened their
season on Tuesday. On Homewood Field DU beat AD, (20-0):
Beta won over Sig Ep, (20-0);
and Phi Gam downed ZBT,
(14-12). On Levering field APL
knocked off ATO, (2-0); Phi Sig
beat KA, (7-0); and Phi Ep won
over TEP,(13-0).
On Monday, October 18, Adams
will play Hollander, Baker will go
against Griffin, and Clark will
battle with Gildersleeve.
Entries for the Goucher Gallop, which will be held on Saturday, October 23, at 12:00 p.m.,
must be in by today. The fraternity tennis tournament - will
begin on October 16 and will end
on October 27.

Edging Toward Win Column,
Gridders Visit Haverford
By MIKE PHILLIPS
Frustrated in two attempts to
reach the victory column, the
varsity football team takes its
hopes for better things to Pennsylvania tomorrow, facing winless Haverford.
The Fords, though unable to
notch a victory since their '63
Hopkins game, are, in the words
of Jay Coach Wilson Fewster,"a
very capable team"—one with
definite offensive potential.
While scoring three touchdowns (and having three called
back) in 15-12 and 33-8 losses to
Delaware Valley and Dickinson,
Haverford has displayed strong
backfield performers including
quarterback Dan Murphy, whose
passing helped dump the Jays
two years ago; breakaway backs
Sam Porrecca and Pete Batzell;
and 5-10 185 pound fullback Don
Urie, a tough inside runner.

felt the team played well enough
to win, and thought that a normally productive offense would
have given it
sizeable lead by
the fourth period.
Lost Pass Rush
"Except for the last minutes,"
he continued, "the defensive line
play was excellent, but whni
Ursinus made its big drive we
lost our pass rush, which put
more pressure on the secondary."
"Also, our defensive backs
were sometimes too worried
about getting beaten deep and
not enough with breaking up
the passes. We really shut down

their running game, though, and
all in all I think we've made
progress."
Game Standouts
Offensively, the varsity mentor thought Henry Schaefer (76
yards on 18 carries plus 3 pass
receptions) and Mike Oidick (5
receptions) stood out, while on
the defensive unit he tabbed the
already-familiar threesome of
Denny Ferrazzano, Shannon. and
Calli, along with Oidick and Ray
Nunnaly.
Following tomorrow's action,
the team returns home to face
Hampden-Sydney October 23
with the kickoff scheduled for
1:30.
